security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with Zod validation patterns and TypeScript code examples. No executable code, no file system access, no network operations, no sensitive data collection.

content.value_statement: Input validation is scattered and error-prone across projects. This skill provides production-ready Zod schemas, error handling patterns, and transformations for consistent, type-safe validation in any TypeScript application.
actual_capabilities: Create schemas for strings, numbers, booleans, dates, arrays, objects, and nested structures
Implement custom validation logic with refinements for complex business rules
Transform and normalize data during validation with built-in and custom transforms
Handle validation errors with custom messages, internationalization, and error formatting
Validate async operations including database checks and API calls
Integrate with Next.js API routes, Server Actions, middleware, and form data
limitations: Does not provide runtime type checking beyond Zod parsing
Does not include database connection or ORM integration code
Does not generate form UI components or validation messages
Requires existing Zod dependency in your project

use_cases.title: Validate API requests
use_cases.description: Validate incoming request bodies, query parameters, and path parameters in API routes with proper error responses

use_cases.title: Validate form submissions

prompt_templates.title: Password validation

prompt_templates.title: Date range validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Zod schema for date ranges where end date must be after start date and the range cannot exceed 30 days

prompt_templates.title: Discriminated union
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a discriminated union schema for API responses with success, error, and loading states, each with their own payload structure

output_examples.input: Create a user registration schema with email, password, confirm password, and optional age field
output: Email: required, valid format, trimmed, lowercase
Password: minimum 8 characters, uppercase, lowercase, number, special character
Confirm password: must match password exactly
Type inference: Full TypeScript type extracted from schema

best_practices: Validate at system boundaries such as API routes, Server Actions, and external data sources
Prefer safeParse over parse to handle validation failures without exceptions
Reuse common schemas across your project for consistent validation rules
Use z.infer to extract TypeScript types from schemas and avoid duplicate type definitions
anti_patterns: Do not re-validate data that has already passed validation in trusted internal functions
Do not use validation for simple type checks where TypeScript types would suffice
Do not ignore validation errors in production even for seemingly trusted data sources
Do not expose raw Zod error objects to clients without formatting

faq.question: What Zod version is supported?
faq.answer: This skill covers Zod v4.1.12 and later versions. Patterns are compatible with the current Zod release.

faq.question: Can I use these patterns with React forms?
faq.answer: Yes. The schemas work with any form library. Use safeParse and format errors for display in React components.

faq.question: How do I handle file upload validation?
faq.answer: Use z.instanceof(File) with refinements for size limits, MIME types, and async checks for image dimensions.

faq.question: Is my data safe with Zod validation?
faq.answer: Yes. Zod validation runs locally in your application. No data is sent to external services unless your code explicitly does so.

faq.question: Why are my validations not running?
faq.answer: Check that you are using parseAsync for async refinements. Ensure refinements return promises for async validation.

faq.question: How does this compare to other validation libraries?
faq.answer: Zod provides type inference, composable schemas, and a developer-friendly API. It integrates naturally with TypeScript without code generation.
